  4. 4 Polyak Stepsize is Gradient Descent on a Surrogate Function
  5. 5 Generalizing the Polyak Stepsize: More Surrogates and Stochastic Setting
    1. 5.1 Stochastic Approximation Setting
  6. 6 Neighbourhood of Convergence and Instability of Polyak Stepsize
  7. 7 Discussion and Limitations
  8. A Proofs for the Surrogate œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï
  9. B Relationship between Star Upper Curvature and Upper Quadratic Growth
  10. C Proofs for the Stochastic Surrogate œàùúì\psiitalic_œà
  11. D Additional Convergence Result for Generalized Polyak Stepsize
  12. E Proofs for Section¬†6

New Perspectives on the Polyak Stepsize:
Surrogate Functions and Negative Results

Francesco Orabona
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)
Thuwal, 23955-6900, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
francesco@orabona.com ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Ryan D‚ÄôOrazio
Mila Qu√©bec AI Institute, Universit√© de Montr√©al
Montr√©al, QC, Canada
ryan.dorazio@mila.quebec
Abstract

The Polyak stepsize has been proven to be a fundamental stepsize in convex optimization, giving near optimal gradient descent rates across a wide range of assumptions. The universality of the Polyak stepsize has also inspired many stochastic variants, with theoretical guarantees and strong empirical performance. Despite the many theoretical results, our understanding of the convergence properties and shortcomings of the Polyak stepsize or its variants is both incomplete and fractured across different analyses. We propose a new, unified, and simple perspective for the Polyak stepsize and its variants as gradient descent on a surrogate loss. We show that each variant is equivalent to minimize a surrogate function with stepsizes that adapt to a guaranteed local curvature. Our general surrogate loss perspective is then used to provide a unified analysis of existing variants across different assumptions. Moreover, we show a number of negative results proving that the non-convergence results in some of the upper bounds is indeed real.

1 Introduction

The iterative optimization of complex functions forms a cornerstone of modern machine learning, scientific computing, and engineering. Among the most foundational first-order methods is gradient descent, which iteratively refines a solution by moving in the direction opposite to the function‚Äôs gradient. A critical aspect of gradient descent is the selection of an appropriate stepsize (or learning rate), as it dictates both the speed of convergence and the stability of the algorithm. The wrong choice of the stepsizes can lead to slow convergence or, conversely, to divergence, making the tuning process a significant practical hurdle.

In this landscape of stepsize selection strategies, the Polyak stepsize, proposed by Polyak (1969) stands out for its theoretical elegance and convergence properties. Starting from an arbitrary ùíô1‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùíô1superscript‚Ñùùëë\boldsymbol{x}_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the Polyak stepsize is defined as

ùíôt+1=ùíôt‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíf‚ãÜ‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2‚Å¢ùíàt,subscriptùíôùë°1subscriptùíôùë°ùëìsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùëì‚ãÜsuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2subscriptùíàùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\frac{f(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-f^{\star}}% {\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}\boldsymbol{g}_{t},bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1)

where ùüé‚â†ùíàt‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíôt)0subscriptùíàùë°ùëìsubscriptùíôùë°\boldsymbol{0}\neq\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})bold_0 ‚â† bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and f‚ãÜ=minùíô‚Å°f‚Å¢(ùíô)superscriptùëì‚ãÜsubscriptùíôùëìùíôf^{\star}=\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). If ùíàt=ùüésubscriptùíàùë°0\boldsymbol{g}_{t}=\boldsymbol{0}bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0, then ùíôt+1=ùíôtsubscriptùíôùë°1subscriptùíôùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This update rule can achieve linear convergence for strongly convex and smooth functions, ùí™‚Å¢(1/T)ùí™1ùëá\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) rate for convex smooth functions, and ùí™‚Å¢(1/T)ùí™1ùëá\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T})caligraphic_O ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) rate for non-smooth convex ones. This is particularly interesting because all of these rates are achieved with a unique stepsize and without knowledge of smoothness or curvature constants. In other words, this update rule is adaptive to the geometry of the functions to optimize.

Recently, the Polyak stepsize has seen a resurgence in the machine learning literature, with a plethora of variants. However, despite the big number of papers on this topic, one essential research question seems still to be missing: What makes the Polyak stepsize adaptive and when can it fail?

Contributions. This paper aims to provide a novel framework to understand the Polyak stepsize, providing a clear geometric explanation of its adaptivity. In particular, we show that the adaptivity is due to a simple but powerful observation: The Polyak stepsize minimizes a surrogate objective function that is always locally smooth. As for standard smooth functions, we will show that the knowledge of the local smoothness constant is enough to obtain the correct rates. In addition, the local smoothness will depend only on the gradient itself, removing the need to estimate it. Furthermore, we show that minimal curvature of the surrogate is inherited from the original function as well. We also use this framework to extend its core idea to a family of algorithms. Then, we will show a number of negative results when f‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)ùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜf(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not known and for its use in the stochastic case. These negative results complete our understanding by showing that some non-vanishing terms in existing upper bounds are necessary.

2 Related Work

In the pionnering work of ¬†Ermol‚Äôev (1966) stepsizes of the form Œ∑t‚àù1/‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2proportional-tosubscriptùúÇùë°1superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\eta_{t}\propto\nicefrac{{1}}{{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù / start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG were proposed for non-smooth optimization. Despite the many convergence guarantees enabled by ¬†Ermol‚Äôev (1966)‚Äôs framework, in ¬†Polyak (1969) it is noted that linear convergence is not possible with such stepsizes. As an alternative, Polyak suggests the stepsize¬†(1), which is shown to converge at favourable rates with non-smooth convex functions, and strongly convex and smooth functions. In fact, contrary to common belief, Polyak (1969) was the first to show linear convergence with a rate comparable to gradient descent in the smooth and strongly convex case. Furthermore, the case where f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is estimated was also studied, showing convergence to a level set if f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is overestimated, and convergence to a neighboorhood if it is underestimated. The Polyak stepsize has since been extended and studied across several applications and domains.

Non-smooth convex. In non-smooth convex optimization, several schemes have been developed to estimate f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the fly¬†(Br√§nnlund, 1993; Bertsekas, 1999; Goffin and Kiwiel, 1999; Sherali et¬†al., 2000; Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001; Kiwiel, 2004). In the finite-sum case with interpolation,¬†(1) and variants have been studied as an incremental subgradient method¬†(Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001; Kiwiel, 2004).

Non-expansive operators. In the context of non-expansive operators, the update¬†(1) has also been studied as a special case of the subgradient projector¬†(Bauschke and Combettes, 2017; Cegielski, 2012; Combettes, 2009). Where it can be shown that subgradient descent with Œ∑t=(f‚Å¢(x)‚àíc)+/‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2subscriptùúÇùë°subscriptùëìùë•ùëêsuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\eta_{t}=\nicefrac{{(f(x)-c)_{+}}}{{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = / start_ARG ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_c ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is a quasi-firmly non-expansive operator111An operator TùëáTitalic_T is quasi-firmly non-expansive if for all fixed points ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ‚ÄñT‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚â§‚Äñùíô‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚àí‚ÄñT‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2superscriptnormùëáùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ2superscriptnormùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ2superscriptnormùëáùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}‚à• italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ‚à• italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that a quasi-firmly non-expansive operators are also referred to as cutters. if fùëìfitalic_f is convex and c‚â•f‚ãÜùëêsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜc\geq f^{\star}italic_c ‚â• italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ùíô‚Üíùíô‚ãÜ‚Üíùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}\to\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x ‚Üí bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if fùëìfitalic_f is continuous¬†(Bauschke and Combettes, 2017). Moreover, in the finite-sum setting, interpolation can also be viewed as iterating different quasi-firmly non-expansive operators with a common fixed point. For example, applying a subgradient projector sequentially (i.e., cycling through the different component functions) in a way such that each function eventually gets visited guarantees that ùíôt‚Üí{f‚Å¢(ùíö)‚â§c}‚Üísubscriptùíôùë°ùëìùíöùëê\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\to\{f(\boldsymbol{y})\leq c\}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí { italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) ‚â§ italic_c }¬†(Cegielski, 2012, Example 5.9.7). For a survey on this topic see¬†Censor (1984).

Deterministic. In modern optimization, (1) has been shown to achieve similar rates to gradient descent in various common assumptions (e.g., Lipschitz, smoothness and strong convexity)¬†(Hazan and Kakade, 2019), and more recently with other assumptions such as weakly convex functions¬†(Davis et¬†al., 2018), (L0,L1)subscriptùêø0subscriptùêø1(L_{0},L_{1})( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-smooth functions¬†(Takezawa et¬†al., 2024; Gorbunov et¬†al., 2025), and directional smoothness¬†(Mishkin et¬†al., 2024).

Stochastic. The Polyak stepsize has also been extended to the stochastic case with emphasis on applications to machine learning¬†(Rolinek and Martius, 2018; Berrada et¬†al., 2020; Loizou et¬†al., 2021; Prazeres and Oberman, 2021). The ALI-G method¬†(Berrada et¬†al., 2020) and SPSmax¬†(Loizou et¬†al., 2021) use stochastic estimates via the sampled function f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)ùëìùíôùùÉf(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) and its gradient ‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚àáùëìùíôùùÉ\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) to perform a Polyak-like stepsize. SPSmax¬†in addition uses infxf‚Å¢(x,ùùÉ)subscriptinfimumùë•ùëìùë•ùùÉ\inf_{x}f(x,\boldsymbol{\xi})roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) as an estimate to f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and is shown to converge at fast rates without a neighbourhood under interpolation. Folowing SPSmax¬†many variants have been proposed for SGD: StoPS¬†(Horv√°th et¬†al., 2022), DECSPS and SPS‚Ñìmaxsuperscriptsubscriptabsent‚Ñì{}_{\max}^{\ell}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT¬†(Orvieto et¬†al., 2022), SPS+subscriptSPS\texttt{SPS}_{+}SPS start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT¬†(Garrigos et¬†al., 2023). Beyond SGD, other extensions include: mirror descent¬†(D‚ÄôOrazio et¬†al., 2023), with preconditioning¬†(Abdukhakimov et¬†al., 2024), with line-search¬†(Jiang and Stich, 2023), and with momentum¬†(Wang et¬†al., 2023; Schaipp et¬†al., 2024; Oikonomou and Loizou, 2025).

Neighbourhood of Convergence. For SPSmax, Loizou et¬†al. (2021) proved that the suboptimality gap is only guaranteed to shrink up to a factor that depends on the loss themselves. As we will explain in Section¬†5.1, this is equivalent to the guarantees in online learning where the regret is proportional to the cumulative loss of the competitor, typically denoted by L‚ãÜsuperscriptùêø‚ãÜL^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, these kind of guarantees are usually called in online learning L‚ãÜsuperscriptùêø‚ãÜL^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bounds¬†(see, e.g., Orabona, 2019, Section 4.2).

Surprisingly enough, despite the adaptivity of the Polyak stepsize across various assumptions without modification, in previous literature there is no clear explanation why this is the case.

3 Definitions and Notation

We will use the following notation and definitions. All the norms in this paper are L2 norms and they will denoted by ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•\|\cdot\|‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à•. For a function f:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, we define a subgradient of fùëìfitalic_f in ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as a vector ùíà‚àà‚Ñùdùíàsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\boldsymbol{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_g ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies f‚Å¢(ùíö)‚â•f‚Å¢(ùíô)+‚ü®ùíà,ùíö‚àíùíô‚ü©,‚àÄùíö‚àà‚Ñùdformulae-sequenceùëìùíöùëìùíôùíàùíöùíôfor-allùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëëf(\boldsymbol{y})\geq f(\boldsymbol{x})+\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-% \boldsymbol{x}\rangle,\ \forall\boldsymbol{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) ‚â• italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) + ‚ü® bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x ‚ü© , ‚àÄ bold_italic_y ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We denote the set of subgradients of fùëìfitalic_f in ùíôùíô\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x by ‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíô)ùëìùíô\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). For a differentiable function we have that ‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíô)={‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíô)}ùëìùíô‚àáùëìùíô\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})=\{\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})\}‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) = { ‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) }. A function f:V‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üíùëâ‚Ñùf:V\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : italic_V ‚Üí blackboard_R, differentiable in an open set containing VùëâVitalic_V, is LùêøLitalic_L-smooth w.r.t. ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•\|\cdot\|‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• if f‚Å¢(ùíö)‚â§f‚Å¢(ùíô)+‚ü®‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíô),ùíö‚àíùíô‚ü©+L2‚Å¢‚Äñùíô‚àíùíö‚Äñ2ùëìùíöùëìùíô‚àáùëìùíôùíöùíôùêø2superscriptnormùíôùíö2f(\boldsymbol{y})\leq f(\boldsymbol{x})+\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}),% \boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y% }\|^{2}italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) ‚â§ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) + ‚ü® ‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x ‚ü© + divide start_ARG italic_L end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_y ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all ùíô,ùíö‚ààVùíôùíöùëâ\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in Vbold_italic_x , bold_italic_y ‚àà italic_V.

Definition 1.

We say that a function fùëìfitalic_f has a sùë†sitalic_s-sharp minimum in ùê±‚ãÜsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if

f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)‚â•s‚Å¢‚Äñùíô‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ.ùëìùíôùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùë†normùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜf(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\geq s\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{% x}^{\star}\|~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â• italic_s ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• .

Note that fùëìfitalic_f has a sharp minimum then it is not differentiable at ùíô‚àósuperscriptùíô‚àó\boldsymbol{x}^{\ast}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT¬†(Polyak, 1987) and if the function is also convex and Gùê∫Gitalic_G-Lipschitz we immediately have G‚â•sùê∫ùë†G\geq sitalic_G ‚â• italic_s.

Definition 2.

We say that a function f:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R is LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded if

‚Äñùíà‚Äñ2‚â§2‚Å¢L‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíinfùíôf‚Å¢(ùíô)),‚àÄùíô‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíô).formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormùíà22ùêøùëìùíôsubscriptinfimumùíôùëìùíôfor-allùíôùëìùíô\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}\leq 2L(f(\boldsymbol{x})-\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})),\ \forall\boldsymbol{x}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})~{}.‚à• bold_italic_g ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ 2 italic_L ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) ) , ‚àÄ bold_italic_x ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) .

It is known that LùêøLitalic_L-smooth functions are LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded¬†(see, e.g., Lemma¬†4 in Li and Orabona, 2019), but this definition is strictly weaker because it does not assume differentiability.

4 Polyak Stepsize is Gradient Descent on a Surrogate Function

Let fùëìfitalic_f be convex and ùíô‚ãÜ‚ààargminùíôf‚Å¢(ùíô)superscriptùíô‚ãÜsubscriptargminùíôùëìùíô\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Consider the following function:

œï‚Å¢(ùíô)=12‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ))2.italic-œïùíô12superscriptùëìùíôùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}\left(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star})\right)^{2}~{}.italic_œï ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (2)

Instead of viewing the Polyak stepsize (1) with respect to fùëìfitalic_f we propose to view it equivalently as a subgradient method with respect to œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï. By the chain rule of subgradients (Bauschke and Combettes, 2017)[Corollary 16.72], subgradient descent with the Polyak stepsize (1) is equivalent to subgradient descent on œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï with stepsize Œ∑t=1‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2subscriptùúÇùë°1superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This perspective may seem superfluous, howerever, we will show that 1‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ21superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is strongly related to a certain notion of local curvature of œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï, local star upper curvature.

Definition 3 (Local star upper curvature (LSUC)).

We say that a function fùëìfitalic_f with minimizer ùê±‚ãÜsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has Œªùê≤subscriptùúÜùê≤\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-local star upper curvature (LSUC) around ùê≤ùê≤\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y if for all ùê≤ùê≤\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y there exists Œªùê≤>0subscriptùúÜùê≤0\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}>0italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 such that

f‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíö)‚àí‚ü®ùíàùíö,ùíô‚ãÜ‚àíùíö‚ü©‚â•12‚Å¢Œªùíö‚Å¢‚Äñùíàùíö‚Äñ22,‚àÄùíàùíö‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíö).formulae-sequenceùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùëìùíösubscriptùíàùíösuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùíö12subscriptùúÜùíösubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàùíö22for-allsubscriptùíàùíöùëìùíöf(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol% {y}},\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2\lambda_{% \boldsymbol{y}}}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}_{2},\ \forall% \boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - ‚ü® bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_y ‚ü© ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚àÄ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) .

Note that the definition implies the convexity of fùëìfitalic_f since we assume the existence of a subgradient.222If ùíàtsubscriptùíàùë°\boldsymbol{g}_{t}bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not a subgradient but a directional derivative then fùëìfitalic_f would be guaranteed to be star-convex¬†(Joulani et¬†al., 2020). It is also immediate to show that convex LùêøLitalic_L-smooth functions are also LùêøLitalic_L-LSUC. Indeed, for convex LùêøLitalic_L-smooth functions we have that¬†(Nesterov, 2004, Theorem 2.1.5)

f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíö)‚àí‚ü®‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíö),ùíô‚àíùíö‚ü©‚â•12‚Å¢L‚Å¢‚Äñ‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àí‚àáf‚Å¢(ùíö)‚Äñ2,‚àÄùíô,ùíö‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequenceùëìùíôùëìùíö‚àáùëìùíöùíôùíö12ùêøsuperscriptnorm‚àáùëìùíô‚àáùëìùíö2for-allùíôùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëëf(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y}),% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2L}\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})% -\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y})\|^{2},\ \forall\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in% \mathbb{R}^{d}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - ‚ü® ‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_y ‚ü© ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG ‚à• ‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - ‚àá italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚àÄ bold_italic_x , bold_italic_y ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

So, it is enough to set ùíô=ùíô‚ãÜùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain the above definition. However, the inclusion is strict, because there exist functions that are not smooth and still satisfy the above definition. For example, one can easily verify that f‚Å¢(x)=|x+2|+x22ùëìùë•ùë•2superscriptùë•22f(x)=|x+2|+\frac{x^{2}}{2}italic_f ( italic_x ) = | italic_x + 2 | + divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG is L‚Å¢S‚Å¢U‚Å¢CùêøùëÜùëàùê∂LSUCitalic_L italic_S italic_U italic_C but not differentiable, so not smooth.

Finally, if the star-upper-curvature holds globally, i.e., there exists 0<Œª<Œªùíö0ùúÜsubscriptùúÜùíö0<\lambda<\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}0 < italic_Œª < italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all ùíöùíö\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y, then we can show that this condition is equivalent to the upper quadratic growth condition in Guille-Escuret et¬†al. (2021). This observation was first made by Goujaud et¬†al. (2022, Theorem 2.6), we include the precise statement and proof in the Appendix¬†B.

The key observation in the next Theorem is that œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï is always locally star upper curved, regardless of the curvature (or lack of it) of the function fùëìfitalic_f. Moreover, it will inherit additional curvature from fùëìfitalic_f. The proof can be found in Appendix¬†A.

Theorem 1 (Curvature of the Polyak surrogate).

Let f‚Å¢(x)ùëìùë•f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) be convex and define ùê±‚ãÜ‚ààargminùê±f‚Å¢(ùê±)superscriptùê±‚ãÜsubscriptargminùê±ùëìùê±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Define œï‚Å¢(ùê±)=12‚Å¢(f‚Å¢(ùê±)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùê±‚ãÜ))2italic-œïùê±12superscriptùëìùê±ùëìsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ2\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^% {2}italic_œï ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have

  • ‚Ä¢

    œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï is ‚Äñùíàùíö‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùíö2\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-LSUC around any ùíöùíö\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y for any ùíàùíö‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíö)subscriptùíàùíöùëìùíö\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If fùëìfitalic_f is sùë†sitalic_s-sharp, then œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï has s2superscriptùë†2s^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-quadratic growth.

  • ‚Ä¢

    If fùëìfitalic_f has Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº-quadratic growth and LùêøLitalic_L-self bounded, then œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï satisfies a local quadratic growth:

    œï‚Å¢(ùíô)‚â•12‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢‚Äñùíà‚Äñ22‚Å¢L‚Å¢‚Äñùíô‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2,‚àÄùíà‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíô).formulae-sequenceitalic-œïùíô12ùúásuperscriptnormùíà22ùêøsuperscriptnormùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ2for-allùíàùëìùíô\phi(\boldsymbol{x})\geq\frac{1}{2}\frac{\mu\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}{2L}\|% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2},\ \forall\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f% (\boldsymbol{x})~{}.italic_œï ( bold_italic_x ) ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Œº ‚à• bold_italic_g ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚àÄ bold_italic_g ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) .

This theorem tells us that, regardless of the curvature of fùëìfitalic_f, we can always construct the function œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï that is locally curved. It is well-known that for LùêøLitalic_L-smooth functions one can use the stepsize Œ∑=1LùúÇ1ùêø\eta=\frac{1}{L}italic_Œ∑ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG and achieve a rate between ùí™‚Å¢(1/T)ùí™1ùëá\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) and a linear one, depending on the presence of strong convexity. Here, we show a similar result: GD can use stepsizes that depend on the local star upper curvature in all cases. Note however, unlike GD with a constant stepsize and smoothness, we do not have a descent lemma with œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï. Indeed this is not possible as it would guarantee a ùí™‚Å¢(1/T)ùí™1ùëá\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) rate for the last iterate which was shown to be impossible by¬†Goujaud et¬†al. (2022) for Q‚Å¢G+(L)ùëÑùê∫ùêøQG+(L)italic_Q italic_G + ( italic_L ) functions (i.e., L-LUSC functions).

Lemma 1.

Let œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï convex and define ùê±‚ãÜ‚ààargminùê±œï‚Å¢(ùê±)superscriptùê±‚ãÜsubscriptargminùê±italic-œïùê±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \phi(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï ( bold_italic_x ). Assume fùëìfitalic_f to be Œªùê±subscriptùúÜùê±\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-LSUC around any point ùê±ùê±\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x. Then, using GD with stepsizes Œ∑t=1Œªùê±tsubscriptùúÇùë°1subscriptùúÜsubscriptùê±ùë°\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}}}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG guarantees

Œ∑t‚Å¢(œï‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíœï‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ))‚â§12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚àí12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt+1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2.subscriptùúÇùë°italic-œïsubscriptùíôùë°italic-œïsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ12superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ212superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\eta_{t}\left(\phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\right)\leq% \frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}~{}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Summing this inequality over time, we also have

œï‚Å¢(ùíô¬ØT)‚Å¢‚àët=1TŒ∑t‚â§‚àët=1TŒ∑t‚Å¢œï‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚â§‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ22,italic-œïsubscript¬Øùíôùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscriptùúÇùë°superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscriptùúÇùë°italic-œïsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ22\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}% \phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\leq\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}% \|^{2}}{2},italic_œï ( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , (4)

where ùê±¬ØT=1‚àët=1TŒ∑t‚Å¢ùê±tsubscript¬Øùê±ùëá1superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscriptùúÇùë°subscriptùê±ùë°\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T}=\frac{1}{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}}\boldsymbol{x}_{t}over¬Ø start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ùê±¬ØT=argminùê±‚àà{ùê±1,‚Ä¶,ùê±T}œï‚Å¢(ùê±)subscript¬Øùê±ùëásubscriptargminùê±subscriptùê±1‚Ä¶subscriptùê±ùëáitalic-œïùê±\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}\in\{% \boldsymbol{x}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{x}_{T}\}}\ \phi(\boldsymbol{x})over¬Ø start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x ‚àà { bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï ( bold_italic_x ).

Proof.

From the classic one-step analysis of GD¬†(see, e.g., Orabona, 2019), we have

Œ∑t‚Å¢‚ü®ùíàùíôt,ùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚ü©=12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚àí12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt+1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2+Œ∑t22‚Å¢‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2.subscriptùúÇùë°subscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°subscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ12superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ212superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2superscriptsubscriptùúÇùë°22superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\displaystyle\eta_{t}\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}},\boldsymbol{x}% _{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol% {x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{% 2}+\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}}{2}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}~{}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü® bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü© = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Now, we use the fact that œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï is LSUC and the definition of Œ∑tsubscriptùúÇùë°\eta_{t}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we obtain the stated bound. Summing from t=1ùë°1t=1italic_t = 1 to TùëáTitalic_T and discarding the negative term on the right hand side concludes the proof. ‚àé

The above discussion can be summarized in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

The Polyak stepsize in (1) is equivalent to subgradient descent on the function œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï in (2), when using stepsizes Œ∑tsubscriptùúÇùë°\eta_{t}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to the inverse of the local-star-upper curvature of œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï in ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This theorem and Lemma¬†1 do not give us a rate, however we can immediately observe that if ‚àëtŒ∑t=+‚àûsubscriptùë°subscriptùúÇùë°\sum_{t}\eta_{t}=+\infty‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = + ‚àû we also have œï‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚Üí0‚Üíitalic-œïsubscriptùíôùë°0\phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\to 0italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚Üí 0, that is, the last iterate will converge.

To obtain known rates for the Polyak stepsize, we can use additional assumptions on fùëìfitalic_f. However, we want to stress that, differently from prior results, we explicitly get a convergence rate for the surrogate function œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï, the function actually minimized by (1). The rates on the original function fùëìfitalic_f are immediate by just taking the square root.

If fùëìfitalic_f is Gùê∫Gitalic_G-Lipschitz, then ‚àët=1TŒ∑t‚â•T/G2superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscriptùúÇùë°ùëásuperscriptùê∫2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}\geq T/G^{2}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• italic_T / italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, the final rate is œï‚Å¢(ùíô¬ØT)‚â§G22‚Å¢T‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2italic-œïsubscript¬Øùíôùëásuperscriptùê∫22ùëásuperscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\leq\frac{G^{2}}{2T}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}italic_œï ( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So, the surrogate loss converges as ùí™‚Å¢(1/T)ùí™1ùëá\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ), as expected by a loss with upper curvature.

Now, instead let‚Äôs assume that the function fùëìfitalic_f is LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded. Using inequalities between harmonic and arithmetic means, we have

1‚àët=1T1‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ2‚â§1T2‚Å¢‚àët=1T‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ2=1T2‚Å¢‚àët=1T‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ4‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ2‚â§1T2‚Å¢‚àët=1T8‚Å¢L2‚Å¢œï‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ2‚â§8‚Å¢L2T2‚Å¢12‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2,1superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëá1superscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°21superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°21superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°4superscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°21superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëá8superscriptùêø2italic-œïsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°28superscriptùêø2superscriptùëá212superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}}\|^{2}}}\leq\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}}\|^{2}=\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}% where in the last inequality we use (4). This implies

œï‚Å¢(ùíô¬ØT)‚â§12‚Å¢‚àët=1TŒ∑t‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2=12‚Å¢‚àët=1T1‚Äñùíàùíôt‚Äñ2‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚â§4‚Å¢L2T2‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ4.italic-œïsubscript¬Øùíôùëá12superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscriptùúÇùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ212superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëá1superscriptnormsubscriptùíàsubscriptùíôùë°2superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ24superscriptùêø2superscriptùëá2superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ4\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\leq\frac{1}{2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}}\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}=\frac{1}{2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{% 1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}}\|^{2}}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\frac{4L^{2}}{T^{2}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{4}~{}.italic_œï ( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT -
