Similarly, it is equally easy to obtain rates for H√∂lder-smooth functions.

We can also assume that fùëìfitalic_f is sùë†sitalic_s-sharp and Gùê∫Gitalic_G-Lipschitz. So, from (3) and the fact that œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï has s2superscriptùë†2s^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quadratic growth from Theorem¬†1, then by Lemma¬†1 we have

s2G2‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚â§s2‚Å¢Œ∑t‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚â§Œ∑t‚Å¢(œï‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíœï‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ))‚â§12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚àí12‚Å¢‚Äñùíôt+1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2.superscriptùë†2superscriptùê∫2superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2superscriptùë†2subscriptùúÇùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2subscriptùúÇùë°italic-œïsubscriptùíôùë°italic-œïsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ12superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ212superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2\frac{s^{2}}{G^{2}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq s^{2}% \eta_{t}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\eta_{t}(\phi(% \boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\leq\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{% x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}~{}.divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_œï ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Using the fact that s2G2‚â§1superscriptùë†2superscriptùê∫21\frac{s^{2}}{G^{2}}\leq 1divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚â§ 1, this immediately gives a linear convergence rate.

5 Generalizing the Polyak Stepsize: More Surrogates and Stochastic Setting

We have shown how the Polyak stepsize is just GD on a particular function with stepsizes adapted to the local curvature of the function. In this section, we show that we can construct an entire family of surrogate losses with similar guarantees, while also preparing ourselves for the stochastic setting.

Instead of the function¬†(2), we consider more generally the surrogate

œà‚Å¢(ùíô)=12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíô),ùúìùíô12superscript‚Ñé2ùíô\psi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x}),italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ,

where h:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•‚Å¢0:‚Ñé‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscript‚Ñù0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq}0italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 is convex. As a special case we can recover¬†(2) with h‚Å¢(ùíô)=f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíf‚ãÜ‚Ñéùíôùëìùíôsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜh(\boldsymbol{x})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-f^{\star}italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, however, in general we do not need to know f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For example we can take h=(f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àía)+‚Ñésubscriptùëìùíôùëéh=(f(\boldsymbol{x})-a)_{+}italic_h = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_a ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any aùëéaitalic_a. Intuitively, the role of h‚Ñéhitalic_h is to transform fùëìfitalic_f into a positive function. We show that œàùúì\psiitalic_œà generally has an approximate local-star-upper curvature, where the approximation stems from h‚Ñéhitalic_h potentially being strictly positive in ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 4 (Approximate local-star-upper curvature).

We will say that a function fùëìfitalic_f with minimizer ùê±‚ãÜsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate Œªùê≤subscriptùúÜùê≤\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-star-upper-curvature around ùê≤ùê≤\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y if there exists œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ such that

f‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíö)‚àí‚ü®ùíàùíö,ùíô‚ãÜ‚àíùíö‚ü©‚â•12‚Å¢Œªùíö‚Å¢‚Äñùíàùíö‚Äñ22‚àíœµ,‚àÄùíàùíö‚àà‚àÇf‚Å¢(ùíö).formulae-sequenceùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùëìùíösubscriptùíàùíösuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùíö12subscriptùúÜùíösubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùíàùíö22italic-œµfor-allsubscriptùíàùíöùëìùíöf(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol% {y}},\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2\lambda_{% \boldsymbol{y}}}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}_{2}-\epsilon,\ \forall% \boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - ‚ü® bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_y ‚ü© ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ , ‚àÄ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) .

Since we do not make explicit assumptions h‚Ñéhitalic_h with respect to fùëìfitalic_f, we can only hope to achieve convergence to the minimum of h‚Ñéhitalic_h or œàùúì\psiitalic_œà. So, from here onward we denote ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as as minizer of œàùúì\psiitalic_œà.

Lemma 2.

Let h:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:‚Ñé‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscript‚Ñùabsent0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be convex. Define œà=12‚Å¢h2ùúì12superscript‚Ñé2\psi=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}italic_œà = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, œàùúì\psiitalic_œà is (2‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(ùê±‚ãÜ)‚àíœà‚Å¢(ùê±‚ãÜ))2ùúìùê±ùúìsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜùúìsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ(2\sqrt{\psi(\boldsymbol{x})\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})}-\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^% {\star}))( 2 square-root start_ARG italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG - italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )-approximate ‚Äñùê†‚Äñnormùê†\|\boldsymbol{g}\|‚à• bold_italic_g ‚à•-LSUC for any ùê†‚àà‚àÇh‚Å¢(ùê±)ùê†‚Ñéùê±\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_g ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ).

Proof.

Given that the function œà‚Å¢(ùíô)ùúìùíô\psi(\boldsymbol{x})italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) might not be differentiable, we have to be careful in the calculation of its subgradients. We have

œà‚Å¢(ùíö)ùúìùíö\displaystyle\psi(\boldsymbol{y})italic_œà ( bold_italic_y ) =12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíö)‚â•12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíô)+h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢[h‚Å¢(ùíö)‚àíh‚Å¢(ùíô)]absent12superscript‚Ñé2ùíö12superscript‚Ñé2ùíô‚Ñéùíôdelimited-[]‚Ñéùíö‚Ñéùíô\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{y})\geq\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol% {x})+h(\boldsymbol{x})[h(\boldsymbol{y})-h(\boldsymbol{x})]= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_y ) ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) + italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) [ italic_h ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ]
‚â•12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíô)+h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢‚ü®ùíà,ùíö‚àíùíô‚ü©=œà‚Å¢(ùíô)+‚ü®h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢ùíà,ùíö‚àíùíô‚ü©,absent12superscript‚Ñé2ùíô‚Ñéùíôùíàùíöùíôùúìùíô‚Ñéùíôùíàùíöùíô\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x})+h(\boldsymbol{x})\langle% \boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle=\psi(\boldsymbol{x})+% \langle h(\boldsymbol{x})\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle,‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) + italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ‚ü® bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x ‚ü© = italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) + ‚ü® italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x ‚ü© ,

where ùíà‚àà‚àÇh‚Å¢(ùíô)ùíà‚Ñéùíô\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_g ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) and the first inequality is due to the fact that 12‚Å¢(‚ãÖ)212superscript‚ãÖ2\frac{1}{2}(\cdot)^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( ‚ãÖ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a convex function. Hence, we see that ùíà~:=h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢ùíàassign~ùíà‚Ñéùíôùíà\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}:=h(\boldsymbol{x})\boldsymbol{g}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG := italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) bold_italic_g is a subgradient of œàùúì\psiitalic_œà in ùíôùíô\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x. Hence, for any ùíñ‚àà‚Ñùdùíñsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_u ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

œà‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àí‚ü®ùíà~,ùíô‚àíùíñ‚ü©+12‚Å¢‚Äñùíà‚Äñ2‚Å¢‚Äñùíà~‚Äñ22ùúìùíô~ùíàùíôùíñ12superscriptnormùíà2subscriptsuperscriptnorm~ùíà22\displaystyle\psi(\boldsymbol{x})-\langle\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}},\boldsymbol{x}% -\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+\frac{1}{2\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g% }}\|^{2}_{2}italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) - ‚ü® over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u ‚ü© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚à• bold_italic_g ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚à• over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =12h2(ùíô))‚àíh(ùíô)‚ü®ùíà,ùíô‚àíùíñ‚ü©+12h(ùíô)2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x}))-h(\boldsymbol{x})\langle% \boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+\frac{1}{2}h(\boldsymbol{x% })^{2}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ‚ü® bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u ‚ü© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢(h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àí‚ü®ùíà,ùíô‚àíùíñ‚ü©)absent‚Ñéùíô‚Ñéùíôùíàùíôùíñ\displaystyle=h(\boldsymbol{x})\left(h(\boldsymbol{x})-\langle\boldsymbol{g},% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle\right)= italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - ‚ü® bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u ‚ü© )
=h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢(h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíh‚Å¢(ùíñ)‚àí‚ü®ùíà,ùíô‚àíùíñ‚ü©+h‚Å¢(ùíñ))absent‚Ñéùíô‚Ñéùíô‚Ñéùíñùíàùíôùíñ‚Ñéùíñ\displaystyle=h(\boldsymbol{x})\left(h(\boldsymbol{x})-h(\boldsymbol{u})-% \langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+h(\boldsymbol{u})\right)= italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) - ‚ü® bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u ‚ü© + italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) )
‚â§h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚ãÖh‚Å¢(ùíñ)=2‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(ùíô)‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(ùíñ),absent‚ãÖ‚Ñéùíô‚Ñéùíñ2ùúìùíôùúìùíñ\displaystyle\leq h(\boldsymbol{x})\cdot h(\boldsymbol{u})=2\sqrt{\psi(% \boldsymbol{x})\psi(\boldsymbol{u})},‚â§ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ‚ãÖ italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) = 2 square-root start_ARG italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ) italic_œà ( bold_italic_u ) end_ARG ,

where the inequality is due to the convexity of h‚Ñéhitalic_h and the fact that h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚â•0‚Ñéùíô0h(\boldsymbol{x})\geq 0italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ‚â• 0. Setting ùíñ‚ààargminùíôœà‚Å¢(ùíô)ùíñsubscriptargminùíôùúìùíô\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \psi(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_u ‚àà roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œà ( bold_italic_x ), we have the stated bound. ‚àé

With approximate local curvature, a generalization of Lemma¬†1 is immediate.

Lemma 3.

Assume œà:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñù\psi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_œà : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R to be œµtsubscriptitalic-œµùë°\epsilon_{t}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximately ŒªtsubscriptùúÜùë°\lambda_{t}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-star-upper-curve around ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, for any Œ∑t>0subscriptùúÇùë°0\eta_{t}>0italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, any ùê†t‚àà‚àÇœà‚Å¢(ùê±t)subscriptùê†ùë°ùúìsubscriptùê±ùë°\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial\psi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ùê±t+1=ùê±t‚àíŒ∑t‚Å¢ùê†tsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùúÇùë°subscriptùê†ùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\eta_{t}\boldsymbol{g}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have

Œ∑t‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíœà‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ))‚â§‚Äñùíô‚ãÜ‚àíùíôt‚Äñ222‚àí‚Äñùíô‚ãÜ‚àíùíôt+1‚Äñ222+Œ∑t2‚Å¢(Œ∑t‚àí1Œªt)‚Å¢‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2+Œ∑t‚Å¢œµt.subscriptùúÇùë°ùúìsubscriptùíôùë°ùúìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜsubscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜsubscriptùíôùë°222subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜsubscriptùíôùë°1222subscriptùúÇùë°2subscriptùúÇùë°1subscriptùúÜùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2subscriptùúÇùë°subscriptitalic-œµùë°\eta_{t}(\psi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\leq\frac{\|% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\|^{2}_{2}}{2}-\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}% ^{\star}-\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}\|^{2}_{2}}{2}+\frac{\eta_{t}}{2}\left(\eta_{t}-% \frac{1}{\lambda_{t}}\right)\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}+\eta_{t}\epsilon_{t}~{}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The last two lemmas tells us that the properties of the surrogate functions breaks if œà‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)‚â†0ùúìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ0\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\neq 0italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â† 0. Hence, we will not be able to prove convergence results, but only that, for example, the suboptimality gap will converge up to a floor that depends on œà‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)ùúìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_œà ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). However, in Section¬†6 we will show that this is not an artifact of the proof. Indeed, we can construct simple one-dimensional functions where the generalized Polyak stepsize does not converge.

5.1 Stochastic Approximation Setting

Consider now the case that we are minimizing F‚Å¢(ùíô):=ùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]assignùêπùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]ùëìùíôùùÉF(\boldsymbol{x}):=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[f(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) := blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ], where f:‚Ñùd√óùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëëùíÆ‚Ñùf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó caligraphic_S ‚Üí blackboard_R, that covers both the stochastic approximation and finite-sum settings. We do not know the distribution Dùê∑Ditalic_D, but we assume that we can sample ùùÉùùÉ\boldsymbol{\xi}bold_italic_Œæ i.i.d. from Dùê∑Ditalic_D.

In this setting, we argue that the Polyak stepsize makes sense only in restricted settings. In fact, the interpretation of the Polyak stepsize as minimizing a surrogate function implies that in the stochastic setting we will minimize the function ùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]subscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]12superscript‚Ñé2ùíôùùÉ\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ], where the function h‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,ùùÉ)‚Ñé‚ãÖùùÉh(\cdot,\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( ‚ãÖ , bold_italic_Œæ ) depends on the particular variant of the stochastic Polyak stepsize. It is clear that in general argminùíôùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]subscriptargminùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]ùëìùíôùùÉ\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}% [f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ] can be completely different from argminùíôùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[12‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]subscriptargminùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]12superscript‚Ñé2ùíôùùÉ\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}% [\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ].

Here, starting from ALI-G¬†(Berrada et¬†al., 2020) and SPSmax¬†(Loizou et¬†al., 2021) that use the idea of limiting the stepsizes, we propose a generalized Polyak stepsize algorithm. The proof is in Appendix¬†C.

Theorem 3.

Let h:‚Ñùd√óùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:‚Ñé‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëëùíÆsubscript‚Ñùabsent0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó caligraphic_S ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be convex. Denote by H‚Å¢(ùê±)=ùîºùõè‚àºD‚Å¢[h‚Å¢(ùê±,ùõè)]ùêªùê±subscriptùîºsimilar-toùõèùê∑delimited-[]‚Ñéùê±ùõèH(\boldsymbol{x})=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[h(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ]. Then, setting Œ∑t=min‚Å°(1‚Äñùê†t‚Äñ2,Œ≥h‚Å¢(ùê±t,ùõèt))subscriptùúÇùë°1superscriptnormsubscriptùê†ùë°2ùõæ‚Ñésubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùõèùë°\eta_{t}=\min\left(\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}},\frac{\gamma}{h(% \boldsymbol{x}_{t},\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})}\right)italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) in Algorithm¬†1, we have

  • ‚Ä¢

    If h‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,ùùÉt)‚Ñé‚ãÖsubscriptùùÉùë°h(\cdot,\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})italic_h ( ‚ãÖ , bold_italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is LùêøLitalic_L-self bounded, we have

    1T‚Å¢‚àët=1Tmin‚Å°(12‚Å¢L,Œ≥)‚Å¢ùîº‚Å¢[H‚Å¢(ùíôt)]‚â§‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2T+2‚Å¢Œ≥‚Å¢H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëá12ùêøùõæùîºdelimited-[]ùêªsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2ùëá2ùõæùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\mathbb{E}[H(% \boldsymbol{x}_{t})]\leq\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2% }}{T}+2\gamma H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Œ≥ ) blackboard_E [ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ‚â§ divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG + 2 italic_Œ≥ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    and

    ‚àët=1Tmin‚Å°(12‚Å¢L,Œ≥)‚Å¢ùîº‚Å¢[H‚Å¢(ùíôt)]‚àíŒ≥‚Å¢‚àët=1TH‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)‚â§12‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2+12‚Å¢‚àët=1TŒ≥2‚Å¢ùîº‚Å¢[‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2].superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëá12ùêøùõæùîºdelimited-[]ùêªsubscriptùíôùë°ùõæsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ12superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ212superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásuperscriptùõæ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\mathbb{E}[H(\boldsymbol{x}_% {t})]-\gamma\sum_{t=1}^{T}H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\leq\frac{1}{2}\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{t=1}^{T}% \gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}[\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}]~{}.‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Œ≥ ) blackboard_E [ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_Œ≥ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .
  • ‚Ä¢

    If h‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,ùùÉt)‚Ñé‚ãÖsubscriptùùÉùë°h(\cdot,\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})italic_h ( ‚ãÖ , bold_italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is Gùê∫Gitalic_G-Lipschitz, then we have

    1T‚Å¢‚àët=1Tùîº‚Å¢[H‚Å¢(ùíôt)]‚â§‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2Œ≥‚Å¢T+2‚Å¢H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)+G‚Å¢‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚ÄñT+G‚Å¢2‚Å¢Œ≥‚Å¢H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ).1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùîºdelimited-[]ùêªsubscriptùíôùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2ùõæùëá2ùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùê∫normsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜùëáùê∫2ùõæùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}[H(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})]\leq\frac{\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}}{\gamma T}+2H(\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star})+\frac{G\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|}{\sqrt{T}}+G\sqrt% {2\gamma H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})}~{}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ‚â§ divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ italic_T end_ARG + 2 italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_G ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_ARG + italic_G square-root start_ARG 2 italic_Œ≥ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG .
  • ‚Ä¢

    If h‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,ùùÉ)‚Ñé‚ãÖùùÉh(\cdot,\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( ‚ãÖ , bold_italic_Œæ ) is LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded and H‚Å¢(ùíô)ùêªùíôH(\boldsymbol{x})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) has Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº-quadratic growth, then

    ùîº‚Å¢[‚ÄñùíôT+1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2]‚â§ùîº‚Å¢[‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ2]‚Å¢aT+1+b‚Å¢1‚àíaT+11‚àía‚Å¢H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ),ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùëá1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùíô1superscriptùíô‚ãÜ2superscriptùëéùëá1ùëè1superscriptùëéùëá11ùëéùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{T+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]\leq% \mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]a^{T+1% }+b\frac{1-a^{T+1}}{1-a}H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}),blackboard_E [ ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚â§ blackboard_E [ ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b divide start_ARG 1 - italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_a end_ARG italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

    where a=Œº2‚Å¢min‚Å°(12‚Å¢L,Œ≥)ùëéùúá212ùêøùõæa=\frac{\mu}{2}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)italic_a = divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Œ≥ ) and b=2‚Å¢Œ≥‚àímin‚Å°(12‚Å¢L,Œ≥)ùëè2ùõæ12ùêøùõæb=2\gamma-\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)italic_b = 2 italic_Œ≥ - roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Œ≥ ).

Choosing the function h‚Ñéhitalic_h, the above theorem covers and extends a number of results in previous papers, for example:

  • ‚Ä¢

    SPSmax (Loizou et¬†al., 2021): h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)=f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚àíinfùíôf‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚ÑéùíôùùÉùëìùíôùùÉsubscriptinfimumùíôùëìùíôùùÉh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-\inf_{% \boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ), so H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)=ùîº‚Å¢[f‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ,ùùÉ)‚àíinfùíôf‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]ùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùùÉsubscriptinfimumùíôùëìùíôùùÉH(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=\mathbb{E}[f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}% )-\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œæ ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ].

  • ‚Ä¢

    SPSmax‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscriptabsent‚Ñì{}^{\ell}_{\max}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Orvieto et¬†al., 2022): h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)=f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚àíq‚Å¢(ùùÉ)‚ÑéùíôùùÉùëìùíôùùÉùëûùùÉh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-q(% \boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) - italic_q ( bold_italic_Œæ ), where q‚Å¢(ùíôi)ùëûsubscriptùíôùëñq(\boldsymbol{x}_{i})italic_q ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a lower bound to infùíôf‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)subscriptinfimumùíôùëìùíôùùÉ\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ). In this case, H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)=ùîº‚Å¢[f‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ,ùùÉ)‚àíq‚Å¢(ùùÉ)]ùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùùÉùëûùùÉH(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=\mathbb{E}[f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}% )-q(\boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œæ ) - italic_q ( bold_italic_Œæ ) ].

  • ‚Ä¢

    SPS+ (Garrigos et¬†al., 2023): h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)=(f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚àíf‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ,ùùÉ))+‚ÑéùíôùùÉsubscriptùëìùíôùùÉùëìsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜùùÉh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=(f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-f(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}))_{+}italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œæ ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, H‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)=0ùêªsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ0H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=0italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 so we can also safely set Œ≥=‚àûùõæ\gamma=\inftyitalic_Œ≥ = ‚àû. Moreover, H‚Å¢(ùíô)‚â•F‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíF‚Å¢(ùíô‚ãÜ)ùêªùíôùêπùíôùêπsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜH(\boldsymbol{x})\geq F(\boldsymbol{x})-F(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) ‚â• italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_F ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), hence any bound on H‚Å¢(ùíô)ùêªùíôH(\boldsymbol{x})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) translates to a bound on the suboptimality gap.

Remark 1.

If h‚Å¢(ùê±‚ãÜ,ùõèt)=0‚Ñésuperscriptùê±‚ãÜsubscriptùõèùë°0h(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})=0italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 for all tùë°titalic_t, then ‚Äñùê±t+1‚àíùê±‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚â§‚Äñùê±t‚àíùê±‚ãÜ‚Äñnormsubscriptùê±ùë°1superscriptùê±‚ãÜnormsubscriptùê±ùë°superscriptùê±‚ãÜ\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à•. Hence, in this case we only need to consider all the properties of h‚Ñéhitalic_h in the bounded domain {ùê±‚àà‚Ñùd:‚Äñùê±‚àíùê±‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚â§‚Äñùê±1‚àíùê±‚ãÜ‚Äñ}conditional-setùê±superscript‚Ñùùëënormùê±superscriptùê±‚ãÜnormsubscriptùê±1superscriptùê±‚ãÜ\{\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|% \leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|\}{ bold_italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ ‚à• bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• }. This is well-known via the subgradient projector perspective, as ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is guaranteed to approach the set ‚ãÇùõè{ùê±:h‚Å¢(ùê±,Œæ)=0}subscriptùõèconditional-setùê±‚Ñéùê±ùúâ0\bigcap_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}\{\boldsymbol{x}:h(\boldsymbol{x},\xi)=0\}‚ãÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { bold_italic_x : italic_h ( bold_italic_x , italic_Œæ ) = 0 } at each iteration if it is non-empty. This property was observed in Gower et¬†al. (2025) for SPS+¬†(Garrigos et¬†al., 2023), but here it holds more generally. For example, h‚Å¢(ùê±,ùõè)=(f‚Å¢(ùê±,ùõè)‚àía)+‚Ñéùê±ùõèsubscriptùëìùê±ùõèùëéh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=(f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-a)_{+}italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) - italic_a ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where a‚â•supŒæminùê±‚Å°f‚Å¢(ùê±,ùõè)ùëésubscriptsupremumùúâsubscriptùê±ùëìùê±ùõèa\geq\sup_{\xi}\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_a ‚â• roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ), would also have no neighbourhood of convergence and satisfies the assumption of the theorem.

Remark 2.

The above theorem also applies to the case where some of the f‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,Œæ)ùëì‚ãÖùúâf(\cdot,\xi)italic_f ( ‚ãÖ , italic_Œæ ) are non-convex functions, while still guaranteeing the convergence to the global optimum of FùêπFitalic_F. For example, consider F‚Å¢(x)=0.5‚Å¢f1‚Å¢(x)+0.5‚Å¢f2‚Å¢(x)ùêπùë•0.5subscriptùëì1ùë•0.5subscriptùëì2ùë•F(x)=0.5f_{1}(x)+0.5f_{2}(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) = 0.5 italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + 0.5 italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), where f1=‚àí|x|subscriptùëì1ùë•f_{1}=-|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - | italic_x | (non-convex) and f2=2‚Å¢|x|subscriptùëì22ùë•f_{2}=2|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 | italic_x |. We have that F‚Å¢(x)=12‚Å¢|x|ùêπùë•12ùë•F(x)=\frac{1}{2}|x|italic_F ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | italic_x | so ùê±‚ãÜ=0superscriptùê±‚ãÜ0\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}=0bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. Now, choose h1‚Å¢(x)=max‚Å°(f1‚Å¢(x)‚àíf1‚Å¢(x‚ãÜ),0)=0subscript‚Ñé1ùë•subscriptùëì1ùë•subscriptùëì1superscriptùë•‚ãÜ00h_{1}(x)=\max(f_{1}(x)-f_{1}(x^{\star}),0)=0italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , 0 ) = 0 and h2‚Å¢(x)=max‚Å°(f2‚Å¢(x)‚àíf2‚Å¢(x‚ãÜ),0)=2‚Å¢|x|subscript‚Ñé2ùë•subscriptùëì2ùë•subscriptùëì2superscriptùë•‚ãÜ02ùë•h_{2}(x)=\max(f_{2}(x)-f_{2}(x^{\star}),0)=2|x|italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , 0 ) = 2 | italic_x |. Hence, the hypotheses of the theorem are verified. Moreover, H‚Å¢(x)=0.5‚Å¢h1‚Å¢(x)+0.5‚Å¢h2‚Å¢(x)‚â•F‚Å¢(x)ùêªùë•0.5subscript‚Ñé1ùë•0.5subscript‚Ñé2ùë•ùêπùë•H(x)=0.5h_{1}(x)+0.5h_{2}(x)\geq F(x)italic_H ( italic_x ) = 0.5 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + 0.5 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ‚â• italic_F ( italic_x ) and H‚Å¢(x‚ãÜ)=0ùêªsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜ0H(x^{\star})=0italic_H ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, so the theorem implies a convergence rate for the minimization of F‚Å¢(x)‚àíF‚Å¢(x‚ãÜ)ùêπùë•ùêπsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜF(x)-F(x^{\star})italic_F ( italic_x ) - italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by using SPS+.

Remark 3.

In the proof of Theorem¬†3, if one stops before taking expectations, one obtains a regret guarantee on a sequence of arbitrary losses h‚Å¢(ùê±,ùõèt)‚Ñéùê±subscriptùõèùë°h(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Such regret scales as the sum of the loss in ùê±‚ãÜsuperscriptùê±‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is exactly the L‚ãÜsuperscriptùêø‚ãÜL^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bound that we mentioned in Section¬†2. Indeed, this kind of updates and guarantees were already obtained in the online learning literature for the special case of linear predictors by the Passive-Aggressive family of algorithms¬†(Crammer et¬†al., 2006).

Besides covering a number of previous algorithmic variants, we also extend the previous known guarantees. In particular, Loizou et¬†al. (2021) did not prove a guarantee for the non-smooth setting. So, our result proves for the first time that SPSmax¬† is adaptive to the entire range of upper curvature of the function, from Lipschitz to smooth functions. In Appendix¬†D we also show additional results. Moreover, the second result in the smooth case is new, and it allows to recover the SGD guarantee on HùêªHitalic_H when Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ is sufficiently small. For example, we include a precise statement for SPS+ when f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)ùëìùíôùùÉf(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) is LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded, that recovers the guarantee in Gower et¬†al. (2025, Corollary 2.3).

6 Neighbourhood of Convergence and Instability of Polyak Stepsize

In Section¬†5 we demonstrate that a generalized version of the Polyak stepsize and existing variants can be viewed as GD on a function with approximate local curvature, with convergence to a neighbourhood of the optimal solution. This neighbourhood of convergence appears in our analysis just like in all existing variants, therefore suggesting it is unavoidable if

H‚Å¢(ùíô)=ùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]>0‚Å¢¬†for all¬†‚Å¢ùíô.ùêªùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]‚ÑéùíôùùÉ0¬†for all¬†ùíô\displaystyle H(\boldsymbol{x})=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[h(% \boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]>0\,\mbox{ for all }\boldsymbol{x}~{}.italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ] > 0 for all bold_italic_x . (5)

In this section, we demonstrate that this neighbourhood of convergence is not an artifact of the analysis and indeed cannot be avoided in general. We also show that the positivity condition¬†(5) can fundamentally change the dynamics of Algorithm¬†1, even in the deterministic setting, thus posing a challenge that is not just associated with interpolation.

Condition¬†(5) occurs with SPS¬†(Loizou et¬†al., 2021) without interpolation, or in the deterministic setting when the optimal value is underestimated, h‚Å¢(ùíô)=f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíc‚Ñéùíôùëìùíôùëêh(\boldsymbol{x})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-citalic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_c where f‚ãÜ>csuperscriptùëì‚ãÜùëêf^{\star}>citalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_c. Convergence under this condition was first studied in the deterministic case in Polyak‚Äôs original paper¬†(Polyak, 1969), where it is shown that if infxh‚Å¢(x)=h‚ãÜ>0subscriptinfimumùë•‚Ñéùë•superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜ0\inf_{x}h(x)=h^{\star}>0roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_x ) = italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 then limt‚Üí‚àûmin1‚â§s‚â§t‚Å°h‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíh‚ãÜ‚â§h‚ãÜsubscript‚Üíùë°subscript1ùë†ùë°‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜ\lim_{t\to\infty}\min_{1\leq s\leq t}h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-h^{\star}\leq h^{\star}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 ‚â§ italic_s ‚â§ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. That is, the best iterate eventually enters a neighbourhood of the minima where the size of the neighbourhood is dependent on how much h‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜh^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is underestimated by 0. In the stochastic case, convergence of the average iterate to a neighbourhood when understimating the minimum was also studied by¬†Orvieto et¬†al. (2022) under SPSmax‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscriptabsent‚Ñì{}^{\ell}_{\max}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, we demonstrate the consequence of condition¬†(5) is far greater than existing results suggest, with instability of fixed points, potential cycles, lower bounds in the sub-optimality gap, and lack of convergence regardless of initialization.

Deterministic Setting. We first demonstrate that in the deterministic setting, for different classes of h‚Ñéhitalic_h, if h‚ãÜ=minx‚Å°h‚Å¢(ùíô)>0superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜsubscriptùë•‚Ñéùíô0h^{\star}=\min_{x}h(\boldsymbol{x})>0italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) > 0, then the fixed points of

ùíôt+1=T‚Å¢(ùíôt):={ùíôt‚àíh‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ2‚Å¢ùíàt,¬†if¬†‚Å¢ùíàt‚àà‚àÇh‚Å¢(ùíôt),‚Äâ0‚àâ‚àÇh‚Å¢(ùíôt),ùíôt,¬†otherwisesubscriptùíôùë°1ùëásubscriptùíôùë°assigncasessubscriptùíôùë°‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°superscriptnormsubscriptùíàùë°2subscriptùíàùë°formulae-sequence¬†if¬†subscriptùíàùë°‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°‚Äâ0‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°subscriptùíôùë°¬†otherwise\displaystyle\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=T(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}):=\begin{cases}% \boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\frac{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}% \boldsymbol{g}_{t},&\mbox{ if }\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}),\,0\notin\partial h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}),\\ \boldsymbol{x}_{t},&\mbox{ otherwise}\end{cases}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := { start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ‚àÇ italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 0 ‚àâ ‚àÇ italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW (6)

are unstable. Intuitively, this can be explained via our surrogate function view: In fact, denoting the local curvature constant of the surrogate 12‚Å¢(h‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíh‚ãÜ)212superscript‚Ñéùíôsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜ2\frac{1}{2}(h(\boldsymbol{x})-h^{\star})^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT around ùíôtsubscriptùíôùë°\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ŒªtsubscriptùúÜùë°\lambda_{t}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we see that the stepsize Œ∑tsubscriptùúÇùë°\eta_{t}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in update (6) can be equivalently written as

Œ∑t=(h‚Å¢(ùíôt)h‚Å¢(ùíôt)‚àíh‚ãÜ)‚Å¢1Œªt.subscriptùúÇùë°‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°‚Ñésubscriptùíôùë°superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜ1subscriptùúÜùë°\displaystyle\eta_{t}=\left(\frac{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})% -h^{\star}}\right)\frac{1}{\lambda_{t}}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (7)

If h‚Ñéhitalic_h is Lipschitz or self-bounded then Œ∑t‚Üí+‚àû‚ÜísubscriptùúÇùë°\eta_{t}\to+\inftyitalic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí + ‚àû as ùíôt‚Üíùíô‚ãÜ‚Üísubscriptùíôùë°superscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\to\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, if h‚Ñéhitalic_h possesses curvature, then ùíôt+1subscriptùíôùë°1\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may move further away from ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT within a neighborhood of ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, in Proposition¬†1 we show that for all self-bounded functions with a quadratic growth condition, the fixed point of TùëáTitalic_T in ¬†(6) is unstable. A similar result can also be shown if h‚Ñéhitalic_h is LùêøLitalic_L-Lipschitz and has a sharp mininum (see Proposition¬†6 in the Appendix).

Proposition 1 (Unstable fixed point).

Suppose h‚Ñéhitalic_h is convex, strictly positive, LùêøLitalic_L-self-bounded, and satisfies the quadratic growth condition h‚Å¢(ùê±)‚àíh‚ãÜ‚â•Œº2‚Å¢‚Äñùê±‚àíùê±‚ãÜ‚Äñ2‚Ñéùê±superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜùúá2superscriptnormùê±superscriptùê±‚ãÜ2h(\boldsymbol{x})-h^{\star}\geq\frac{\mu}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star}\|^{2}italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ùê±‚ãÜ=arg‚Å°minùê±‚Å°h‚Å¢(ùê±)superscriptùê±‚ãÜsubscriptùê±‚Ñéùê±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) is the only fixed point of TùëáTitalic_T, defined in¬†(6). Then, for any point ùê±‚ààS={ùê≤:ùê≤‚â†ùê±‚ãÜ,h‚Å¢(ùê≤)‚àíh‚ãÜ<h‚ãÜ‚Å¢Œº8‚Å¢L‚àíŒº}ùê±ùëÜconditional-setùê≤formulae-sequenceùê≤superscriptùê±‚ãÜ‚Ñéùê≤superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜùúá8ùêøùúá\boldsymbol{x}\in S=\{\boldsymbol{y}:\boldsymbol{y}\neq\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},% h(\boldsymbol{y})-h^{\star}<h^{\star}\frac{\mu}{8L-\mu}\}bold_italic_x ‚àà italic_S = { bold_italic_y : bold_italic_y ‚â† bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_L - italic_Œº end_ARG } we have

‚ÄñT‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ>‚Äñùíô‚àíùíô‚ãÜ‚Äñ.normùëáùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜnormùíôsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|>\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star}\|~{}.‚à• italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• > ‚à• bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• .

Note that this reinforces the need to clip the stepsize as proposed in ALI-G and SPSmax. However, clipping will not remove this behaviour unless the maximum value is taken to be small enough. In Proposition¬†5 we show there is always a subregion where the stepsize is bounded, and this subregion can be made arbitrarily large within the unstable region; therefore, if the clipped value is too large instability is unavoidable.

The importance of h>0‚Ñé0h>0italic_h > 0 in update¬†(6) has also been studied in Bauschke et¬†al. (2018), where they demonstrate with examples that TùëáTitalic_T can fail to be quasi-firmly non-expansive if h‚ãÜ>0superscript‚Ñé‚ãÜ0h^{\star}>0italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0. Propositions ¬†1, and ¬†6 provide extra insight on this phenomenon as they automatically prove TùëáTitalic_T cannot be quasi-firmly non-expansive and therefore we have the following remark.

Remark 4.

If h>0‚Ñé0h>0italic_h > 0, and either of the following conditions hold:

  • ‚Ä¢

    h‚Ñéhitalic_h is convex, self-bounded, and satisfies the quadratic growth condition,

  • ‚Ä¢

    h‚Ñéhitalic_h is convex, Lipschitz, and has a sharp minimum,

then TùëáTitalic_T from (6) is not quasi-firmly non-expansive.

While Lemmas¬†1¬†and¬†6 establish that minima can be unstable, this property may not fully describe the dynamics of update¬†(6). In fact, instability can admit convergence in the average iterate or last iterate if the local critical neighborhood is skipped. So, in Proposition¬†2 we provide an example of a function h‚Ñéhitalic_h, which satisfies the assumptions of Proposition¬†1, where the iterates cycle and never reach the minimum in best iterate or on average.

Proposition 2 (Cycling and failure to converge).

There exists a strictly positive smooth and strongly convex function h‚Ñéhitalic_h, and an initial point ùê±1subscriptùê±1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that iterates from update¬†(6) cycle and satisfy the inequality h‚Å¢(1t‚Å¢‚àëi=1tùê±i)‚àíh‚ãÜ‚â•Œ¥>0‚Ñé1ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùë°subscriptùê±ùëñsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜùõø0h(\frac{1}{t}\sum_{i=1}^{t}\boldsymbol{x}_{i})-h^{\star}\geq\delta>0italic_h ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• italic_Œ¥ > 0 for all tùë°titalic_t.

Note that since the cycle in Proposition¬†2 consists of a finite number of points, clipping will not necessarily remove this behaviour (e.g. if the clipped value is taken to be larger than any of the seen stepsizes). In Proposition¬†2, a specific initialization was chosen to construct a cycle that would not converge. However, in Proposition¬†3 we show that for 1-d quadratics the lack of convergence is true for all initializations and values of h‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜh^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT up to a set of measure zero.

Proposition 3 (The set of good initializations can have measure zero).

Let h:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñé‚Üí‚Ñù‚Ñùh:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : blackboard_R ‚Üí blackboard_R, defined as h‚Å¢(x)=x22+a‚Ñéùë•superscriptùë•22ùëéh(x)=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+aitalic_h ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_a for a>0ùëé0a>0italic_a > 0, where xt+1=xt‚àíh‚Å¢(xt)‚Äñ‚àáh‚Å¢(xt)‚Äñ2‚Å¢‚àáh‚Å¢(xt)subscriptùë•ùë°1subscriptùë•ùë°‚Ñésubscriptùë•ùë°superscriptnorm‚àá‚Ñésubscriptùë•ùë°2‚àá‚Ñésubscriptùë•ùë°x_{t+1}=x_{t}-\frac{h(x_{t})}{\|\nabla h(x_{t})\|^{2}}\nabla h(x_{t})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• ‚àá italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚àá italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ùê±1subscriptùê±1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is randomly initialized. Then, P‚Å¢{limt‚Üí‚àûxt=x‚ãÜ}=0ùëÉsubscript‚Üíùë°subscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•‚ãÜ0P\{\lim_{t\to\infty}x_{t}=x^{\star}\}=0italic_P { roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } = 0. In other words, the set of initializations that can converge to the optimal solution has measure zero.

Proof.

Note h‚Ñéhitalic_h is 1-smooth and 1-strongly convex and therefore satisfies the conditions of Proposition 1 with Œº=L=1ùúáùêø1\mu=L=1italic_Œº = italic_L = 1 and an unstable unique fixed point. Let TùëáTitalic_T be such that xt+1=T‚Å¢(xt)subscriptùë•ùë°1ùëásubscriptùë•ùë°x_{t+1}=T(x_{t})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). T‚Å¢(x)=x‚Å¢(12‚àíax2)ùëáùë•ùë•12ùëésuperscriptùë•2T(x)=x\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{x^{2}}\right)italic_T ( italic_x ) = italic_x ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_a end_ARG start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) if x‚â†0ùë•0x\neq 0italic_x ‚â† 0 and 00 otherwise. With inverse T‚àí1‚Å¢(S)={x¬±x2+2‚Å¢a:x‚ààS}superscriptùëá1ùëÜconditional-setplus-or-minusùë•superscriptùë•22ùëéùë•ùëÜT^{-1}(S)=\{x\pm\sqrt{x^{2}+2a}:x\in S\}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S ) = { italic_x ¬± square-root start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_a end_ARG : italic_x ‚àà italic_S }. Therefore, T‚àík‚Å¢({x‚ãÜ})superscriptùëáùëòsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜT^{-k}(\{x^{\star}\})italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) has at most 2ksuperscript2ùëò2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT points which has measure zero for all kùëòkitalic_k. By Lemma¬†6 in Appendix¬†E, the result follows. ‚àé

Remark 5.

Note that, by Lemma¬†6, Proposition¬†3 can be extended much more generally if TùëáTitalic_T from (6) is shown to satisfy the Lusin (N‚àí1superscriptùëÅ1N^{-1}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) property¬†(Hencl and Koskela, 2014, Definition 4.12).

In the stochastic case with SPS, condition¬†(5) is due to lack of interpolation, and Orvieto et¬†al. (2022) show that it can change the expected fixed point. In contrast, in the deterministic setting we have shown lack of convergence despite the fixed point being ùíô‚ãÜsuperscriptùíô‚ãÜ\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore the issue here stems from the instability of the method due to the under estimation of h‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñé‚ãÜh^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and not the bias of the expected update.

Stochastic case. In the stochastic setting, the positivity condition¬†(5) can occur despite minùíô‚Å°h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)=0subscriptùíô‚ÑéùíôùùÉ0\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}h(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=0roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = 0, such as in SPS¬†(h‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)=f‚Å¢(ùíô)‚àíminùíô‚Å°f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)‚ÑéùíôùùÉùëìùíôsubscriptùíôùëìùíôùùÉh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(% \boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ )) without interpolation. Orvieto et¬†al. (2022) demonstrate that without interpolation SPS¬†can fail to converge in a 1-d quadratic and has an expected fixed point different than minùíô‚Å°F‚Å¢(ùíô)=minùíô‚Å°ùîºùùÉ‚àºD‚Å¢[f‚Å¢(ùíô,ùùÉ)]subscriptùíôùêπùíôsubscriptùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùùÉùê∑delimited-[]ùëìùíôùùÉ\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}F(\boldsymbol{x})=\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\mathbb{E}_{% \boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œæ ‚àº italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Œæ ) ]. Similarly to the deterministic setting, we can show that SPS can have a random walk between a finite number of points.

Proposition 4 (Failure to converge).

There exist f1subscriptùëì1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f2subscriptùëì2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT quadratic 1-d functions and a starting point x1subscriptùë•1x_{1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that SPS on F‚Å¢(x)=0.5‚Å¢(f1‚Å¢(x)+f2‚Å¢(x))ùêπùë•0.5subscriptùëì1ùë•subscriptùëì2ùë•F(x)=0.5(f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x))italic_F ( italic_x ) = 0.5 ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) satisfies

ùîº‚Å¢[F‚Å¢(xt)]‚àíminx‚Å°F‚Å¢(x)‚â•2/3,‚àÄt.ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùë•ùë°subscriptùë•ùêπùë•23for-allùë°\mathbb{E}[F(x_{t})]-\min_{x}\ F(x)\geq 2/3,\ \forall t~{}.blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_x ) ‚â• 2 / 3 , ‚àÄ italic_t .
Proof.

Let f1=x2+2‚Å¢x+5subscriptùëì1superscriptùë•22ùë•5f_{1}=x^{2}+2x+5italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_x + 5 and f2‚Å¢(x)=2‚Å¢x2‚àí4‚Å¢x+10subscriptùëì2ùë•2superscriptùë•24ùë•10f_{2}(x)=2x^{2}-4x+10italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = 2 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_x + 10. Let‚Äôs start from x1=1subscriptùë•11x_{1}=1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 where F‚Å¢(x1)=8ùêπsubscriptùë•18F(x_{1})=8italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 8. If we draw f1subscriptùëì1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, x2=‚àí1subscriptùë•21x_{2}=-1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 1, while if we draw f2subscriptùëì2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then x2=1subscriptùë•21x_{2}=1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 because f2‚Ä≤‚Å¢(1)=0superscriptsubscriptùëì2‚Ä≤10f_{2}^{\prime}(1)=0italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) = 0. Hence, ùîº‚Å¢[F‚Å¢(x2)]=0.5‚Å¢f1‚Å¢(1)+f2‚Å¢(1)2+0.5‚Å¢f1‚Å¢(‚àí1)+f2‚Å¢(‚àí1)2=9ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùë•20.5subscriptùëì11subscriptùëì2120.5subscriptùëì11subscriptùëì2129\mathbb{E}[F(x_{2})]=0.5\frac{f_{1}(1)+f_{2}(1)}{2}+0.5\frac{f_{1}(-1)+f_{2}(-% 1)}{2}=9blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = 0.5 divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 0.5 divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - 1 ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 9. Iterating, we have that x3subscriptùë•3x_{3}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has equal probability to be equal to 1 and -1. Hence, again we have ùîº‚Å¢[F‚Å¢(x3)]=9ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùë•39\mathbb{E}[F(x_{3})]=9blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = 9. So, we have that this holds for any tùë°titalic_t. Moreover, we have that minx‚Å°F‚Å¢(x)=44/6subscriptùë•ùêπùë•446\min_{x}F(x)=44/6roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_x ) = 44 / 6. ‚àé

7 Discussion and Limitations

We have shown that the design, properties, and failure of the (variants) of the Polyak stepsize can be easily derived through the lens of the minimization of a surrogate objective function. This framework also provides a new and natural explanation on the adaptivity of the stepsize via the local curvature of the surrogate. We believe this framework has the promise to design new variants, by simply designing surrogate functions with the required properties. Furthermore, with our perspective we have provided new insight on the challenge of controlling neighbourhoods of convergence that often appear in variants of the Polyak stepsize. We demonstrate that this neighbourhood is not avoidable and a fundamental issue beyond interpolation causing instability.

The limitations of our framework include the assumption of convex h‚Ñéhitalic_h in the generalized surrogate that must be assumed apriori. It is unclear if this framework can be extended to the more general case of noncovex surrogate functions. The class of such surrogates that admit fast rates and tight neighbourhoods of convergence remains an open question that we leave to future work.

Acknowledgments

We acknowledge the use of Gemini 2.5 in developing the proof of Proposition¬†2. We also thank Mehdi Inane Ahmed for helpful discussions.
